stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Malware Identified in Web Injection Campaign Targeting Banks
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 18 July 2014, the malicious file chqpl.exe (MD5: c6315a09e06e2ba775e5be0979d23755) was identified in a campaign against multiple financial institutions in the United Kingdom and United States.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the report, this malware was identified as Dyre or Dyreza. Its capabilities include a backdoor, form grabbing, Web injection, and data theft.
It creates the following registry key: \REGISTRY\USER\S-1-5-21-344981575-398944299-1130229096-1000\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\GoogleUpdate = C:\Users\admin\AppData\Local\googleupdaterr.exe
The malware copies itself to: C:\Users\[User]\AppData\Local\googleupdaterr.exe
It injects into the target process explorer.exe, along with web browser processes iexplorer.exe, firefox.exe, and chrome.exe.
This malware attempts to determine the public-facing internet protocol (IP) information using the following: icanhazip.com
The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) may be used to identify public-facing IP information from these publicly accessible Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN) servers: stun.callwithus.com stun.sipgate.net stun.ekiga.net stun.ideasip.com stun.internetcalls.com stun.phonepower.com stun.2talk.co.nz stun.voipstunt.com
A User-Agent string identified as associated with this network is: User-Agent: Wget/1.9

The malware sends the following GET request:
GET /cho1118/WIN-8KQKJNLLEH_W617601.6505A35FA47BDFC4862FD3580EFB6F7B/5/publickey/[REDACTED]/ HTTP/1.1 User-Agent: Opera/9.80 Host: 94.23.2.19:19000
